item.title: From algae to yeast: the quest to find an alternative to palm oil
item.description:
From algae to yeast: the quest to find an alternative to palm oil

When green cleaning company Ecover announced the launch of a new laundry liquid containing an oil made from algae, as an alternative to the palm oil used in most detergents, it wasn't prepared for the backlash. The problem? The algae producing the oil were genetically modified.

item.title: No title
item.description:
Human populations are increasing and so is uncertainty regarding food and water supplies. Since all of our food is initially sourced by photosynthetic primary producers, we need to discover those producers that can grow fastest and that can grow in the widest variety of environmental conditions. With this knowledge, we will be able to supply the needs of the growing human population.

,

Micro-plant-tech is the way to do this. By utilising the core strengths of photosynthetic microbial primary producers, we will be able to produce food, fuel, cosmetics and medicines to meet the growing need of the developing world.

item.title: The genome and phenome of the green alga Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 reveal adaptive traits for desert acclimatization
item.description:
The genome and phenome of the green alga Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007 reveal adaptive traits for desert acclimatization

Genomics and Evolutionary Biology Plant Biology Abstract To investigate the phenomic and genomic traits that allow green algae to survive in deserts, we characterized a ubiquitous species, Chloroidium sp. UTEX 3007, which we isolated from multiple locations in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Metabolomic analyses of Chloroidium sp.

item.title: Systems level analysis of the Chlamydomonas reinhardtii metabolic network reveals variability in evolutionary co-conservation - Molecular BioSystems (RSC Publishing) DOI:10.1039/C6MB00237D
item.description:
Systems level analysis of the Chlamydomonas reinhardtii metabolic network reveals variability in evolutionary co-conservation - Molecular BioSystems (RSC Publishing) DOI:10.1039/C6MB00237D

Metabolic networks, which are mathematical representations of organismal metabolism, are reconstructed to provide computational platforms to guide metabolic engineering experiments and explore fundamental questions on metabolism. Systems level analyses, such as interrogation of phylogenetic relationships within the network, can provide further guidance on the modification of metabolic circuitries.
